title: Measurement of RNA-induced PKR Activation in vitro
procedures: Human PKR gene cloning   RNA isolation and cDNA library generation   Grow the cells in a 35 mm dish with 10 ml DMEM with 10% FBS and 1% penicillin-streptomycin in a 37 °C incubator with 5% CO2 until 80% confluence.   Remove the media from the culture dish.   Add 1 ml TRIzol reagent directly to the cells in the culture dish.   Pipette the cells up and down for 5 times in the culture dish to lyse the cells.   Incubate the sample at room temperature for 5 min to allow for complete nuclear lysis.   Add 0.2 ml of chloroform and share the tube vigorously by hand for 15 sec.   Incubate for 2 min at room temperature.   Centrifuge the sample at 12,000 x g for 15 min at 4 °C.   Remove the aqueous supernatant by angling the tube at 45° to avoid contacting the interphase or the organic layer.   Transfer the aqueous phase into a new tube and add 0.5 ml of 100% isopropanol.   Incubate at room temperature for 10 min.   Centrifuge at 12,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.  Note: RNA should be visible as a white pellet.   Remove the supernatant carefully from the tube without touching the RNA pellet.   Wash the pellet with 1 ml of 75% ethanol pre-chilled at 4 °C.   Vortex the sample briefly, followed by centrifugation at 7,600 x g for 5 min at 4 °C.   Remove the ethanol carefully and air dry the RNA pellet for 15 min on ice.   Re-suspend the RNA pellet in 100 μl DEPC-treated water and incubate at 37 °C for 10 min.   Measure the RNA concentration using a Qubit 3.0 Fluorometer, NanoDrop spectrophotometer or Bioanalyzer.   Prepare the 5x iScript cDNA Synthesis reaction mix on ice for reverse transcription. imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20170315/20170315104211_1007.

jpg    Incubate the reaction mix on a PCR machine with the following program: 5 min at 25 °C 30 min at 42 °C 5 min at 85 °C Hold at 4 °C   Store the cDNA in aliquots at -20 °C. Alternatively, store the cDNA at 4 °C if used repeatedly in days. Avoid repeated freezing and thawing cycles.     PCR amplification and subcloning into pET-28a+ plasmid Other bacterial expression plasmids may be used. Different restriction enzymes may be used in other plasmids depending on the cloning sites.    Amplify the human PKR gene with the following primers: Forward: 5’ TAGTCGACATGGCTGGTGATCTTTCAGC 3’ Reverse: 5’ GTCAGCCTAACATGTGTGTCGTTCATTTTTCTC 3’ Notes:    The forward primer contains a SalI restriction site, as underlined, before the start codon.   Only a single band will be obtained.     Prepare a PCR reaction mix on ice as follow imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20170315/20170315104126_5422.jpg    Incubate the reaction mix on a PCR machine with the following program: imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20170315/20170315104301_9507.jpg    Incubate the following reaction mix to produce the product with an overhang imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20170315/20170315104356_1110.jpg    Prepare the following reaction mix for subcloning the PKR gene into the pGEM-T Easy vector   imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20170315/20170315104420_2314.jpg    Incubate the ligation reaction mix at 4 °C overnight. .    Transformation into E. coli    Thaw One Shot TOP 10 chemically competent cells on ice for 3 min.   Add 5 μl ligation product to the cells.   Incubate the tube on ice for 30 min.   Place the tube at room temperature for 10 min.   Mix 50 μl β-galactoside (X-Gal) (50 mg/ml) to 150 μl SOC medium and add the mixture to the LB plate with ampicillin.   Spread the transformed cells on the LB plate with ampicillin.    Incubate the plate at 37 °C overnight.   Pick the white colonies to check for successful ligation of PKR gene.    Digestion and ligation of PKR gene into pET-28a+    Set up SalI and NotI digestion reactions for pET-28a+ and PKR imgsrc:https://en-cdn.

bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20170315/20170315104517_7267.jpg  imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20170315/20170315104536_5114.jpg    Run the double digestion products pET-28a+ and PKR separately on a 1% agarose gel. Note: Look for the bands for pET-28a and PKR at 5,369 bp and 1,656 bp, respectively.   Carefully excise the bands from the gel using clean razor blades.   Perform gel extraction using the QIAGEN Gel Extraction Kit.   Weigh the gel slice in a tube and add 3 volumes buffer QG to 1 volume gel.   Incubate at 50 °C for 10 min.   Add 1 gel volume isopropanol to the sample and vortex.   Transfer the sample to the QlAquick column and centrifuge for 1 min at 18,000 x g.   Add 750 ml buffer PE to the QlAquick column and centrifuge for 1 min at 18,000 x g.   Add 50 μl buffer EB to the center of the QlAquick membrane to elute the DNA.   Set up a ligation reaction to subclone PKR gene into the pET-28a plasmid imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20170315/20170315104726_0163.jpg    Incubate at 16 °C overnight and transform 2 μl of the reaction into 25 μl competent cells.       PKR protein purification from E. coli   Grow the cells in LB broth at 37 °C until OD600 reaches 0.4-0.6.   Induce with 40 µl of a 100 mM IPTG (final concentration 400 µM) for 3 to 5 h at 37 °C.   Harvest the cells and proceed immediately to cell lysis or freeze the cells in liquid nitrogen followed by storing them at -80 °C.   Resuspend the cells in lysis buffer at 2-5 ml per gram wet weight.   Add lysozyme (1 mg/ml) to the lysis buffer with the cells and incubate on ice for 30 min.   Sonicate on ice using a sonicator equipped with a microtip. Note: Use five 15 sec bursts at 30x with a 45 sec cooling period between each burst.

(Optional) If the lysate is very viscous, add RNase A (10 μg/ml) and DNase I (5 μg/ml) and incubate on ice for 10-15 min.   Centrifuge lysate at 10,000 x g for 20-30 min at 4 °C to pellet the cellular debris and keep the supernatant.   Add 5 μl 2x LDS-PAGE sample buffer to 5 μl supernatant and store at -20 °C for LDS-PAGE analysis.   Pipette 10 ml of Ni-NTA slurry to a 50 ml tube and briefly centrifuge. Remove supernatant and add 20 ml of lysis buffer. Mix gently by inverting. Repeat centrifugation step and remove the supernatant. Note: Adjust the amount of Ni-NTA used depending on the yield of the target protein.   Add cleared lysate to this equilibrated matrix and mix gently by shaking at 4 °C for 1 h.   Load 10 ml lysate-Ni-NTA mixture into a column.   Remove bottom cap and collect the flow-through. Save and store for Western blotting.   Wash 10 times with wash buffer. Collect wash factions for Western blotting.   Elute protein 4 times with 1 ml elution buffer.   Perform dialysis in storage buffer overnight at 4 °C.   Wet the dialysis tube with distilled water and close the tube with a clip near one end.   Load the sample into the dialysis tube and clip another end.   Immerse the knotted tube in storage buffer in a 500 ml beaker overnight.   Measure protein concentration by Qubit Protein Assay and check the purity of protein (Figure 1).  imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20170315/20170315102130_4048.jpg Figure 1. Silver staining of purified PKR protein. The purified PKR protein (65 kDa) was visualized by silver staining. IPTG was added to induce the protein expression in E. coli. Lysate from cells without IPTG induction was used as a negative control.      PKR dephosphorylation and activation Human PKR protein is activated by the RNAs from E.

coli upon cell lysis; therefore, protein dephosphorylation is necessary to obtain the non-phosphorylated form of PKR before activation assays.   Dephosphorylation of PKR    Incubate 2 μg of PKR with 400 U λ-PPase (1 μl) in 10 μl phosphatase reaction buffer for 1 h at 30 °C.   Aliquot the dephosphorylated PKR into 10 tubes each containing 0.2 μg PKR protein   Add freshly prepared 2 mM sodium orthovanadate to inhibit the λ-PPase.    In vitro PKR activation assay    Prepare 10 μg/ml Poly I:C from stock (as a positive control) (10 mg/ml).   Make the reaction mixture on ice. imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20170315/20170315104644_3138.jpg    Incubate dephosphorylated PKR with 10 ng Poly I:C or dsRNA in PKR activation buffer at 30 °C for 0.5-2 h.   Add 1x LDS loading buffer with 5% β-mercaptoethanol to stop the reaction.   Perform Western blotting to determine the PKR activation by probing for level p-PKR against total PKR.   Electrophorese the samples through a NuPAGE 4-12% Bis-Tris protein gel.   Transfer the resolved proteins onto an immobilon-P polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) membrane at 100 V for 90 min at 4 °C.   Block the membrane with 1% bovine serum albumin in 0.5% Tween-20 phosphate buffered saline (PBST) for 60 min.   Incubate the membrane with primary antibody overnight at 4 °C.   Wash the membrane three times with PBST for 5 min each.   Add horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody at a dilution of 1:3,000 for 1 h at room temperature.   Wash the membrane three times with PBST for 5 min each.   Add enhanced chemiluminescence detection system (ECL reagents).   Scan the membrane with a Typhoon scanner (Figure 2).  imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20170315/20170315102609_7907.jpg Figure 2. Representative results of PKR activation in vitro. PKR activation assay was used to study different types of RNAs (mRNAs, small RNAs and rRNAs) isolated from WT and NIPBL-MS (missense) human lymphoblastoid cell lines (LCLs).

Both ncRNAs and rRNAs isolated from NIPBL-MS LCLs are capable of activating recombinant PKR in vitro; 10 ng Poly I:C was used as a positive control for PKR activation. *P < 0.001 compared to untreated control. (Please refer to Yuen et al., 2016 for details)
